intro: Telmatophace, commonly known as the "marsh face" plant, is a genus of flowering plants belonging to the family Asteraceae. These plants are typically found in wetland and marsh environments, where they thrive in moist, nutrient-rich soils. Telmatophace species are characterized by their narrow, grass-like leaves and small, clustered flowers that often have a yellow or white coloration. They play an important role in stabilizing wetland ecosystems by preventing soil erosion. Due to their habitat preferences, they are often indicators of healthy, undisturbed wetland environments.
